channel.title: Models by me
channel.description:
Admin cape, Its pretty bad ass, I got the neck guard from count dracula. I thought it might make it diffrent from all the others. By the way dont go and start making that for those dumb skillcapes recolors. Which i used a normal skillcape but took off everything and added my stuff >>
~~Admin cape~~
[img]http://i41.tinypic.com/xbi9lw.jpg[/img]
[img]http://i41.tinypic.com/2whl95e.jpg[/img]
~~Mod cape~~
[img]http://i41.tinypic.com/op4do6.png[/img]
Rate them please some comments would be appreciated. I might aswell release some. :P

item.title: Models by me
item.dc:creator: @the_wanderer The Wanderer
item.description:
@the_wanderer wrote:

thunderflea:

i know im gravedigging in dangerous territory, but. i love this cape man, its nice!! the coloring is weird though, please release man those are sweet

If you want someone to release you something or you have questions on an old topic PM them and don’t gravedig or as you say “gravedig in dangerous territory.”

item.title: Models by me
item.dc:creator: @rip4d rip4d
item.description:
@rip4d wrote:

For connecting two points, select them and hit CTRL+J, it will join the two vertices. And for smoothing out prims, I think reyx posted something in the model help section, it might come in handy for you.

Read full topic

item.title: Models by me
item.dc:creator: @_s_oldie_R (s)oldie(R)
item.description:
@_s_oldie_R wrote:

Thanks for all the great suggestions guys, im working on prims more and more, im finding them effective and useful, what i dont know how to do is connecting them…? Like if i have 2 rectangles that i want to gonnect point to point how would I do that? thats been holding me back. I am afraid to ask though since you know… “” NOOB FUCKER FUCKITY BITCH YOUR A NOOB CUZ U DONT KNOW HOW TO DO SIMPLE SHIT’’. Ill definately be using prims more.

PS: You know how primatives have edges that are sharp? How do I dull them out. SO it is smooth and nice.

Read full topic

item.title: Models by me
item.dc:creator: @rip4d rip4d
item.description:
@rip4d wrote:

[quote=“Orngequirrel, post:9, topic:336173”][quote author=rip4d link=topic=432553.msg3176197#msg3176197 date=1270867459]

IMO they aren’t that great.

Try to not use “Primitive” objects for modeling. They can be hard to handle with and look ugly if not fixed up.

Now I’m not saying prims are bad, it’s just that you aren’t modifying them enough.
[/quote]Wat.

Primitives are the best form of modeling. Just because someone doesn’t know how to use the full extent of them yet doesn’t mean they shouldn’t use them, as the only way to get better is through practice.

(S)oldie®, definitely practice using primitive models more. Once you get better, its amazing what you can do. This was my first real primitive model: http://i97.photobucket.com/albums/l214/lionray/PFlailRender3.png , and this was my most recent one: http://img97.imageshack.us/img97/1623/icesword.png .

Once you get good enough, you’ll be surprised at the progress you make. These models are fine, but you should definitely start learning to manipulate them. At that point, you shouldn’t need to use bases for your models

Nononoonnoo, you obviously didn’t bother to read the rest of my post.

“Now I’m not saying prims are bad, it’s just that you aren’t modifying them enough.”

I’m trying to suggest that he should start off with something else, perhaps with lines and faces, simple stuff, I created a few things with it, but I’m not a great modeler so…
http://img176.imageshack.us/img176/6441/mymodels.mp4[/quote]Thats why I said to practice

Read full topic

IMO they aren’t that great.

Try to not use “Primitive” objects for modeling. They can be hard to handle with and look ugly if not fixed up.

Now I’m not saying prims are bad, it’s just that you aren’t modifying them enough.
[/quote]Wat.

Primitives are the best form of modeling. Just because someone doesn’t know how to use the full extent of them yet doesn’t mean they shouldn’t use them, as the only way to get better is through practice.

(S)oldie®, definitely practice using primitive models more. Once you get better, its amazing what you can do. This was my first real primitive model: http://i97.photobucket.com/albums/l214/lionray/PFlailRender3.png , and this was my most recent one: http://img97.imageshack.us/img97/1623/icesword.png .

Once you get good enough, you’ll be surprised at the progress you make. These models are fine, but you should definitely start learning to manipulate them. At that point, you shouldn’t need to use bases for your models ;)[/quote]

http://img176.imageshack.us/img176/6441/mymodels.mp4

item.title: Models by me
item.dc:creator: @reyx7 reyx7
item.description:
@reyx7 wrote:

[quote=“rip4d, post:7, topic:336173”][quote author=reyx7 link=topic=432553.msg3176198#msg3176198 date=1270867554]
Best way to mess with primitives is just doing simple stuff like deleting faces, re-connecting them with the create tool, move some points around, ect. ect.
[/quote]I find rotating and moving, scaling, and simply dragging effective enough. Deleting and reconnecting faces isn’t very efficient imo.[/quote]
I find it useful for that prim that looks like this

2s1ublg.jpg701×401

Read full topic

item.title: Models by me
item.dc:creator: @rip4d rip4d
item.description:
@rip4d wrote:

[quote=“Orngequirrel, post:4, topic:336173”]IMO they aren’t that great.

Try to not use “Primitive” objects for modeling. They can be hard to handle with and look ugly if not fixed up.

Now I’m not saying prims are bad, it’s just that you aren’t modifying them enough.[/quote]Wat.

Primitives are the best form of modeling. Just because someone doesn’t know how to use the full extent of them yet doesn’t mean they shouldn’t use them, as the only way to get better is through practice.

(S)oldie®, definitely practice using primitive models more. Once you get better, its amazing what you can do. This was my first real primitive model: http://i97.photobucket.com/albums/l214/lionray/PFlailRender3.png , and this was my most recent one: http://img97.imageshack.us/img97/1623/icesword.png .

Once you get good enough, you’ll be surprised at the progress you make. These models are fine, but you should definitely start learning to manipulate them. At that point, you shouldn’t need to use bases for your models
